title: State leaders say money is sitting around with the budget impasse
text:
State leaders say money is sitting around with the budget impasse 
Updated: Mon, Oct 19 2015, 05:12 PM 
By: CBS 21 Web Staff HARRISBURG, Pa. -- A new group of Republican state lawmakers is proposing a way to provide financial support for schools and human services as the Commonwealth continues to function months since a budget was supposed to be in place.The lawmakers say the fiscal lifelines plan they are proposing would use the $6 billion in tax money collected since the budget impasse began 111 days ago.The money would go to different schools and services that aren't receiving state funding because no budget has been passed."And they're all amounts that everyone at the table has previously agreed on. These are amounts where the governor requested a certain amount of funding. We provided that amount or even a bigger amount," Rep. Stephen Bloom said.Bloom, who represents Cumberland County, said the money is just sitting in the treasury and not being used.Gov. Tom Wolf has not signed a budget into law, citing the proposals presented to him by the Republican-controlled General Assembly do not address significant issues, including pension and education funding reforms.
